awd_titl_txt: Conference Workshops on Global Elections Data Resources
awd_abstract_narration:
There is considerable interest in local-level data on election returns, and on voting and turnout behavior, but collections of data at global scale are incomplete or hard to access.  This award supports two workshops as first steps (building on the Constituency Level Elections Archive (CLEA) in developing an enhanced, high-quality, and more comprehensive new resource, The Election Archive (THEA) archiving local level election data from around the world. The workshops will allow for the effective design of this new data resource, which will help researchers and policy makers evaluate election processes in a large number of political contexts. 

This award supports two conference workshops, one virtual and one in-person/hybrid, with two  overriding goals: first, to gather together experts on data from elections around the world to share research findings and contribute their expertise and, second, to broaden and diversify the network of researchers involved in The Election Archive (THEA), to be introduced in 2022 or 2023.    THEA will build on available resources, especially Constituency Level Elections Archive (CLEA), which has existed since 2006, and has been funded in part by NSF over multiple grants.  The workshops engage a wide range of social scientists and representatives of potential user communities to advise on research community needs and priorities, and provide opportunities for student participants to gain useful skills in data analysis. 

This award is supported by the Accountable Institutions and Behavior Program and the Security and Preparedness Program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
There is considerable interest in subnational data on election returns and voting and turnout behavior. This project entailed two scientific conference workshops regarding such data. The workshops focused on how to develop The Constituency Level Elections Archive (CLEA) into a new elections resource, The Elections Archive (THEA), in ways that are informed by the interests and needs of the user community.   

CLEA already makes significant contributions to the field, serving as the basis for dozens of publications, conference papers, and theses. CLEA is an award-winning archive, affording the greatest geographic and temporal scope, innovative indicators, extensive documentation on political and electoral systems, and tools to customize output to user needs. Via the website (https://electiondataarchive.org/), anyone can easily download results and related information for free. The archive has a multi-decade record of achievements highlighted by regular releases of additional data, new products developed for the research community, and substantial growth in its audience and usage. 

First, we held an online conference in January 2022 with four sets of researchers, grouped generally by topic area of expertise. Four conference sessions were organized over the course of two weeks with the leaders of CLEA. Participants were researchers from around the world—including from non-academic research organizations—who use election data. Many experts on these Zoom calls have sterling research reputations and are quite senior, but participants also included early-career scholars and practitioners. They were given scenarios for building THEA and were asked to comment during an open discussion.

Second, we held an in-person conference, in September 2022, in Montreal as part of the annual meeting of the American Political Science Association. We held an open call for researchers to present their own research using subnational data and participate in conversations about THEA. Those attending in Montreal were mostly early-career researchers or graduate students along with some senior researchers. 

These two conferences in January and September were very successful not only for developing networks of researchers using comparative election data, but also for getting feedback about the potential development of THEA. Based on the feedback we received from this diverse set of researchers, we identified the following priorities: (1) expanding data collection to include senate and presidential election returns at the subnational level, (2) expanding efforts to collect geo-referenced data through THEA’s GeoReferenced Electoral Districts Datasets, and (3) providing a clearinghouse for subnational data of other sorts, including data on subnational elections.

An additional goal of this grant was to diversify the group of researchers involved with THEA. Diversity of perspectives and backgrounds adds immense value to scientific and organizational collaborations. We invited people to our conferences with the goal of adding people from diverse backgrounds and demographic groups to the THEA leadership team, making a special effort to include more women, people from underrepresented minority groups, and international participants.
